para.paratext:
There is no limit to the kinds of physical objects that can be received as demonstrative evidence as long as they are relevant and will aid the jury.[
1]
Objects such as a light pole crossarm[2] and a sidewalk standard[3] have been introduced in evidence.

The weapon or weapons used in the commission of a crime are generally admissible.[
4] Bullet casings and projectiles are also admissible.[
5]

Where the police have gathered evidence at the scene of a crime, and the prosecution attempts to introduce the evidence against a defendant, the evidence being introduced at trial must be the same as the evidence gathered at the scene of the crime. Thus, “when the State seeks to introduce into evidence an item that is subject to the chain of custody rule, it must establish with reasonable assurance that the item seized is the same as the item being offered into evidence.”
[6]

However, the court acts within its discretion where it allows the admission of a distinct and recognizable item into evidence, such as blood-stained shoes, even where every person responsible for the chain of control has not testified.[
7] Moreover, the state is not required to foreclose very possibility of tampering; it need only show reasonable assurance of the identity of the evidence.[
8]

Older cases allowed clothing worn by either the victim or the defendant to be admitted in a rape prosecution,[9] but of course this is now restricted under the rape shield statute.[
10]
Other objects properly received in evidence are too numerous to list in detail.

If the object is especially gruesome and calculated to inflame the jury, some jurisdictions will exclude it unless the fact involved cannot be established by other evidence. For example, the South Carolina Supreme Court upheld excluding an eye from evidence where the plaintiff's eye had been removed as the result of an injury.[
11]

However, in Georgia, any relevant object is admissible in evidence, no matter how gruesome. In a prosecution for murder by way of illegal abortion, the Georgia Supreme Court upheld the trial court's decision to admit into evidence jars containing the aborted fetus and certain organs of the deceased mother and to leave these items in front of the jury for much of the trial.[
12]

Where an article is introduced as a standard of comparison, preliminary evidence showing that in essential respects it offers a trustworthy comparison is sufficient to allow it. In Baez v. State ,[13] the state properly used handguns that were unrelated to the defendant's alleged armed robbery as demonstrative evidence at trial.[
14 ] The handguns were merely shown to the victim to allow him to determine which gun was similar to the one that he claimed was used to rob him.

In Hudson v. State ,[15] the court allowed the prosecutor throughout an armed robbery trial to keep on its counsel table in full view of the jury a shotgun which had been found in the vicinity where the defendant had been apprehended, which the victim was unable to positively identify and which was not introduced into evidence. The record failed to show that defense counsel made any objection insofar as matter was concerned, and no ruling was involved regarding the matter.

In Carver v. Kinnett ,[16] the court held a syringe and needle admissible during direct examination after the plaintiff testified that these items were like the syringe and needle used to treat him to demonstrate the type of suffering that the plaintiff had undergone during treatment and to rebut defense arguments implying that the plaintiff was malingering.
O.C.G.A. § 17-5-50[18] provides for the admissibility of photographs or other identification in lieu of certain physical objects, and for their return after trial.

Ga. Sup. Ct. R. 71 provides as follows:

Where a party relies upon physical evidence on appeal that was proffered at trial, the party shall see that a description or a photograph of the physical evidence, together with an explanation of it, if helpful, is included within the transcript, in lieu of sending the original evidence.

If the party who is relying upon physical evidence deems the original evidence to be of such importance that a photograph or a description cannot suffice to demonstrate the party's contention, application may be made to the trial court for an order directing the transmission of the original evidence to this Court, or application may be made to this Court for such an order if it cannot be obtained from the trial court after a bona fide effort.
Where the admissibility of photographs is attacked, the originals or exact duplicates, to be furnished by appellant, shall be included in the transcript.
The court reporter and clerk shall certify the exhibits.
Similarly, Ga. Ct. of Appeals R. 21 provides as follows:

Any party relying on physical evidence may include as a part of the transcript or record a photograph, a video or an audio recording of the evidence, together with an explanation or description, if deemed necessary, in lieu of transmitting the original evidence. No original evidence or exhibits shall be transmitted to the Court unless the Court directs the clerk of the trial court to transmit such original evidence or exhibits, or upon the grant of a written motion of the party or parties desiring such original evidence or exhibits to be transmitted to the Court. The motion shall be specific as to what original evidence or exhibits shall be transmitted to the Court and the reason such original evidence or exhibits are necessary for the determination of the appeal. After the remittitur has been issued from the Court to the trial court, all original evidence or exhibits shall be returned to the clerk of the trial court. In no event, unless directed by this Court, shall physical evidence be transmitted to the Court which is bulky, cumbersome, or expensive to transport, or which, by reason of its nature, is dangerous to handle, or which is contraband. Any video or audio recording of evidence shall be submitted to the Court of Appeals in one of the following formats: VHS, DVD, video or audio CD, or audio cassette tape.

Former law made no provision for return of physical objects to the defendant after trial. In Cannington v. State, 154 Ga. App. 557, 269 S.E.2d 62 (1980), the defendant moved for the return of his property that had been used as evidence by the State. The motion was denied. The court affirmed. Photographs involved had been destroyed by order of the court, so this issue was moot. The weapon used in the commission of the crime was contraband under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-51 and would be disposed of under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-52. The “door” had evidentiary value for the state and could be retained for a reasonable length of time for various post-conviction actions that might arise. Determination of a reasonable length of time was for the trial court and there was no abuse of discretion in this case.

O.C.G.A. § 17-5-50 still fails to make provision for the return of physical objects to the defendant after trial. It does give a defendant who is claiming ownership of property the right to a hearing to “determine the ownership of such property.”
Even if this section is read along with O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30 as to a motion to suppress, the result is not clear. It would seem that the Cannington case above would apply.
Recoba v. State, 167 Ga. App. 447, 306 S.E.2d 713 (1983), held that, at a hearing under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-50, the court could also determine the rights of third-party claimants as to the property.

In State v. Collins, 171 Ga. App. 225, 319 S.E.2d 84 (1984), Collins had been charged with theft by extortion of $2,000 from Ford Motor Credit Corporation. The state seized the money and gave it to Ford. Collins was then acquitted and sued the state for the money. The court held that, under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-50, he need not notify the attorney general but that the statute did not waive the sovereign immunity of the state and he could not sue the state.

For the present consideration, subsection (c) provides: “Photographs, video tapes, or other identification or analysis of the property involved, duly identified in writing by the law enforcement officer originally taking custody of the property as accurately representing such property, shall be admissible at trial in lieu of the original property.”
Gunter v. State, 182 Ga. App. 548, 356 S.E.2d 276 (1987), and LoGiudice v. State, 164 Ga. App. 709, 297 S.E.2d 499 (1982), involved the return of seized firearms under O.C.G.A. § 17-5-2 .
